title: The sum of the numbers divisible by 7 between the 100 to 300 will be? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll add a caveat to your question — as written, the answer is “infinite,” as every real number between 100 and 300 can be divided by 7, although not all of them are evenly divisible (for example, 50*Pi is in between 100 and 300, but [50*Pi/7] is not a whole number). So, I’ll answer the related question, “How many whole numbers between 100 and 300 are evenly divisible by 7?” Let’s start with finding the smallest and largest numbers that fit. The smallest number greater than 100 evenly divisible by 7 is 105, or 7*15. The largest number less than 300 evenly divisible by 7 is 294, or 7*42. Every number that can be written as 7*N where N is between 15 and 42 is evenly divisible by 7 and between 100 and 300. So now, you know that the list you’re looking for is the list of numbers [7*15, 7*16, … , 7*42]. Drop the “7*” from each element, and you’ve got a list of 15 through 42. Shift that back so the first element is 1 (subtract 14 from each, basically), and you’ve got 1 through 28. There are 28 numbers evenly divisible by 7 between 100 and 300.

Numbers between 100 to 300 that are divisible by 7 are 105, 112, 119, 126….. 294 This is arithmetic progression where common difference is 7, 1st term is 105, last term = 294 Total number of terms = {(last term - 1st term)/ common difference } + 1 ={ (294–105)/7 } + 1 = 27 + 1 = 28 terms Sum of AP = n(1st term + last term)/2 n is number of terms Sum = 28(105+294)/2 = 14(399) = 14*(400–1) = 5600 - 14 = 5586 (Ans)
